name: hylotelephium-anacampseros
country-or-region-of-origin: Pyrenees, Southwest to Southern Alps, South Central Alps
distribution:
and North Italy
Introduced: Czechoslovakia and Norway
wildlife-value: This a pollinator plant for bees and butterflies. It also provides shelter for small wildlife.
edibility: The plant leaves are reportedly edible but bitter. They can be served either raw or cooked.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Allow the seed heads to dry on the plant, then remove and collect the seeds.
flower-description: The flowerheads are tight and round. The flowers are star-shaped and cluster at the end of the stem.  They are purplish-red on the interior and have a purple covered powdery bloom on the outside.
leaf-description: The leaves are grayish-green to bluish-green.  They are rounded and up to 1.2 inches in diameter.
stem-description: The stems decumbent, sparsely branched, and measure 6-8 inches long.  The leaves are mostly arranged toward the tips of the reddish to pale green-colored stems.
uses: This plant is grown commercially for use as a "green roof or "green wall" system. In Germany, it is cultivated as a medicinal plant.  A poultice can be made from mashed leaves.
